title: Zero & First Conditionals
description: Learn to talk about facts, general truths, and real possibilities using conditional sentences.

rules.title: Zero Conditional Structure
rules.explanation: Use the zero conditional to talk about facts, general truths, and things that always happen. Both parts use present simple.

examples.sentence: If you heat water to 100 degrees, it boils.
If students don't study, they usually fail exams.
examples.translation: 학생들이 공부하지 않으면 보통 시험에 떨어져요.

examples.sentence: Water freezes if the temperature drops below zero.

rules.title: First Conditional Structure
rules.explanation: Use the first conditional to talk about real possibilities in the future. Use present simple after 'if' and will/won't in the main clause.
rules.structure: If + present simple, will + base verb

examples.sentence: If I study hard, I will pass the exam.
If you don't hurry, you will miss the bus.
We will have a picnic if the weather is nice.

rules.title: Difference Between Zero and First Conditional
rules.explanation: Zero conditional = always true, general facts. First conditional = specific future possibilities that may or may not happen.

examples.sentence: If you don't eat, you get hungry. (zero - always true)
If you don't eat lunch, you will be hungry later. (first - specific future)
examples.translation: 점심을 안 먹으면 나중에 배고플 거예요. (특정 미래)

rules.title: Unless in Conditionals
rules.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not'. It can replace 'if not' in conditional sentences.

examples.sentence: Unless you study, you won't pass. = If you don't study, you won't pass.
I won't go unless you come with me.
examples.translation: 당신이 같이 가지 않으면 나는 안 갈 거예요.

examples.sentence: Unless it rains, we will have the event outside.
examples.translation: 비가 오지 않으면 행사를 야외에서 할 거예요.

rules.title: Modals in First Conditional
rules.explanation: You can use other modals instead of 'will' in the main clause: can, could, may, might, should.
rules.structure: If + present simple, modal + base verb

examples.sentence: If you finish early, you can leave.
If it rains, we might cancel the trip.
examples.translation: 비가 오면 여행을 취소할 수도 있어요.

examples.sentence: If you have any questions, you should ask the teacher.

rules.title: Time Clauses with When/As soon as
rules.explanation: Use 'when', 'as soon as', 'before', 'after', 'until' like 'if' - with present simple for future meaning.
rules.structure: When/As soon as + present simple, will + base verb

examples.sentence: When I graduate, I will look for a job.
As soon as class finishes, I will call you.
I will wait until you are ready.

exercises.question: If she studies hard, she _____ (pass) the exam.
_____ you don't hurry, you will be late.
Unless you _____ (help) me, I won't finish on time.
If it rains tomorrow, we _____ stay home.
When I _____ (see) him, I will give him your message.
If you finish your homework, you _____ watch TV.

exercises.original: If you don't practice, you won't improve.
exercises.answer: Unless you practice, you won't improve.

exercises.question: As soon as class _____, I will go to the library.
If you mix yellow and blue, you _____ (get) green.
